bioghist.p: George William Brown (1870-1932) received his Ph.D. in Sanskrit, Hebrew, and Arabic from Johns Hopkins University under the direction of Maurice Bloomfield. Brown taught at Central Christian College, before going to Harda and Jubbulpore in South India, where he worked as a missionary of the Disciples of Christ for 16 years. From 1917 to 1921 he was Professor of Semitic languages at the College of the Bible, Transylvania University, and from 1921 to 1927 he was Dean of the Faculty and Professor of Indology at the College of Missions at Indianapolis. Brown was a founding member of the Linguistic Society of America. His son, W. Norman Brown, was also a noted Sanskrit scholar.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of George William Brown. Materials include: research notes and a typescript for a history of the Disciples of Christ in India; research notes for and typescripts of "History of Missions in India"; notes on Hittites, Dravidians, Elamites, Etruscans, Sumerians, Hurri, Churri and the Mittani and Dravidian languages; a review of a Nepali etymological dictionary; notes on the Synoptic Gospels; typescript of an analysis of the Tulsi Das Ramayana; and a series of lecture notes on China, linguistic and language study, comparative philology, and the Old Testament.
